p.s: Shakespeare wrote many different sonnets with many different topics.
But there is one thing that appears in most of them and that is love.
So in the following I am going to deal with his different ways of reflecting about this topic.
In his sonnets,Shakespeare talks about different aspects which are important when you think of love.
He deals with topics like death, lies, trust and all that in a romantic way.
when you readShakespeare for the first time you will most likely not understand the context or the words he uses.
He writes in a way that he paraphrases words we know to diffretdifferent ones to give it a better meaning.
He chooses every word perfectly so it fits into what he wants to point out.
When he talks about love, his words always have a deeper meaning and when you read it 4-5 times you will always find another way to interpretateinterpret his texts.
Like when I first read Sonnet 18 in my englishEnglish class I didn't know it was about death and eternal love until I went through it a couple of times.

As a student I have to admit that reading his sonnets for the first time was a bit annoying, but when you start to work on them and read a bit more it gets better to understand them and the most important part because otherwise you can't really enjoy them.
His perspective of love is really interesting because he writes his feelings down without trying to hide anything.
That in my opinion makes them even better because you can relate to them on a more deeper level.
He shows good but also bad sides of loving someone and shows that in his sonnets.
If someone wants to readShakespeare for the first time I as a student would recommend learning more about his language because otherwise itsit's hard to understand.
